BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1914.

VARSITY SHOWED POOR OFFENSE

PRESIDENT GOODNOW FETED
Baltimore Alumni of Columbia Banquet
• Former Eton Professor at Maryland
Club—Distinguished Guests.

President Frank J. Goodnow was
the guest of honor at a banquet
given Saturday night at the Maryland Club by the Baltimore alumni
of Columbia University in which
Dr. Goodnow was a professor before being called to the presidency
of Johns Hopkins.
As a special compliment to President Goodnow there were among
the speakers Dr. Nicholas Murray
Butler, president of Columbia; Prof.
Talcott Williams, dean of the Pulitzer School of Journalism of Columbia, and Benjamin B. Lawrence,
a mining engineer of New York
and the first trustee of Columbia
elected by the alumni organization.
N. Winslow Williams, former
Secretary of State of Maryland,
who was graduated from Columbia
in 1883, was toastmaster, and
among the 6o guests were several
from out of the city, in addition
to the speakers. These included
James Brown Scott, secretary of
the Carnegie Peace Endowment,
of Washington, and Dr. Marcus
Benjamin, who is president of the
Columbia Alumni Club of that city.
There were no set speeches, but
the general trend of the extemporaneous remarks was congratulation to Baltimore that Hopkins had
been so fortunate as to obtain for
its head a man of the calibre and
learning of Dr. Goodnow. From
President Butler came the note of
regret that Dr. Goodnow had decided to leave Columbia.
While most of the speeches were
by no means serious, President
Goodnow took occasion to touch
upon the big problem which confronts him as executive head of
such an institution as Hopkins. He
declared that ever since his arrival
he had been asked what his policy
would be with respect to the University.
"It is. hard for me to make them
understand," he explained, "that I
have no policy yet; that before
making any plans for the future
which might affect the administration of the affairs of the University I will first have to study the
situation with utmost care and find
out what is best to be done."
Dr. William H. Welch, whose
speech followed that of the toastmaster, referred to the care with
which the trustees of Hopkins had
selected its president.
His remarks were recalled by
President Butler, who complained
that Columbia was getting to be too
much of a national market for university presidents and professors,

NEW POWER-HOUSE AT HOMEWOOD NEARING COMPLETION

The interior of the power-house
at Homewood has taken on quite a
changed appearance in the past
few weeks. Bricklayers, boiler
setters and pipe fitters have gone.
In their place there are a few
negroes straightening up, and a
few electricians connecting the dynamos and switchboards.
In the boiler-room one finds all
four boilers bricked in, and one
burning in order to heat the buildings which are now in use. It is
one of the two equipped with the
Ronney mechanical stokers, and the
ease with which it may be attended
would make old Mr. Sapp, who
fires the boilers in McCoy Hall,
quite envious. The other boiler,
equipped with the Ronney stoker,
is finished, as are also the two of
the Taylor blast type. The stack
is now being put on the superheater, and when this is done the
boiler-room will be finished.
In the pumproom adjoining,
everything is also practically completed, and the feed pumps are
working.
The three dynamos, two turbines
and one reciprocating engine, which
together comprise three units, are
all set up in the engine room, and
only need a few connections before
they begin generating current. The
switch boards which control the
whole of the new plant are also in
this room, and are now being
wired. For the. present light is obtained from outside sources. The
engine room is directly over the
pumproom.
It is only in the northern part
of the power-house where the gas
and steam engine laboratories are
to be that the incomplete appearance remains. This is because
much of the machinery has not yet
come, and because most of the
contractor's efforts have been toward getting the boilers ready.
Now that this work has been
finished, work on the laboratory

GLEE CLUB MAKES GREAT
STRIDES WITH NEW MUSIC

The members of the .\ I usical
Clubs are hard at work. Under
the direction of their respective
leaders, the Glee and Instrumental
squads have been rehearsing diligently at frequent intervals and are
producing results which promise
something really good at concerts
of the coming season. The Glee
Club has made remarkable strides.
In one of the recent rehearsals an
entire song was worked through.
The Instrumental men have some
rather difficult music to learn, and
in spite of the fact that they rehearse only once a week, have accomplished much. The music to
be rendered this year by both clubs
has been pronounced by those who
have heard it the best that the clubs
have ever had, and with the new
plans of handling the men, especially on the Glee Club, a wellrounded aggregation .of musicians
is expected to represent Johns Hopkins this year.
Concerts will be arranged in the
near future, the first to take place
probably about Christmas time. A
Christmas trip will not be taken this
year, owing to the short time which
the clubs have had for preparation,
and to the fact that it is very hard
to pay bills for a Christmas trip at
the beginning of the season, when
there is very little money in the
treasury. The bad debts due to
trips such as these are what the
present management is trying to
avoid altogether, in order to place
the organization on a firm financial
basis. Therefore, whatever trips
are made will be taken after there
has been some money made through
chnrch concerts and other local engagements, Mills for some very
attractive trips are being considered
by the Board of Governors.

Played Creditable Defensive Came, But
Attack Was Disappointing—Western
Maryland Won,6 to 0.
By AN OLD PLAYER.

The fact that Coach Cates was
not at Homewood to see the game
between Johns Hopkins and West
em Maryland will save the members of our team from the good
scolding which they deserve. Western Maryland won by a score of
6 to o. It would have been larger
had not the 'Varsity played such
a creditable defensive game.
But it makes no difference how
strong the defense is, a team is
worth very little or nothing if it
has not developed a good attack.
Hopkins has, or had, an attack that
was excellent—we need only to
look to the Gettysburg and Washington College games to see this.
But on Saturday the attack was
not strong enough to make more
than a couple of first downs. Why?
The backfield men stopped whenever a tackle was imminent. Bob
Hoffman was the only man who
made his tacklers work. The
others slowed down as soon as an
arm was raised before them.
Furthermore, there was no interference worth mentioning. The
squad has worked hard to develop
plays which specify a definite interference for the man with the
ball. The plays work well in practice: there is always a man before
the runner. But on Saturday, it
appeared that a lesson had never
been given in interference.
And what is more, I have never
seen a team so slow in signals, in
passing the ball and in getting off
on a run. Every second must
count; you know that: But a regular sermon in signals was read
off to the players. It took nearly
three-quarters of.a minute to pass
around the numbers for the play,
and many times it was necessary to
hold a little consultation in which
the numbers were explained. Why
should this be? Doesn't every man
know the signals? Captain Wilkinson was not wholly to blame for
this condition. It took him a long
time to call the signals, but it was
apparently necessary, for the backfield (with the exception of Hoffman) did not readily grasp them.
The defeat may be ascribed to
the slowness of the backfield and
its lack of "pep." I hope this will
not be the case in the St. John's
game. It would be better for the
men to sit up all night and learn
the signals than to have had sleep
and not know them in the most important game of the season.
But the lack of attack was neutralized by the excellent offense.

FINAL BATTLE WITH ST. JOHN'S

A SWIMMING TEAM PROPOSED

'Varsity's Rivals From Annapolis Wil
Close Football Season Thanksgiving.
Records Since 1888.

With the Number of Good Men Available
It Is Hoped Team Can Be Formed
to Represent Hopkins.

St. John's College, boasting one
of the strongest and best balanced
football teams it has ever had, will
meet the 'Varsity Thanksgiving
afternoon in the final game of the
season. The Annapolis team is
slightly the favorite, but Hopkins
is unwilling to concede that it will
have a walk-away as St. John's
now predicts.
The team will come to Baltimore supported by the entire student body, and will have a band.
Hopkins, too, will turn out in solid
• array, and will have its hired
musicians, as is customary for this
occasion. There will be a massmeeting in Hopkins Hall at one
o'clock Wednesday, at which details for assembling and cheering
stand arrangement will be explained.
Johns Hopkins and St. John's
have met on the gridiron twentyfour times since 1888. St. John's
has won twelve games, and Hopkins nine. There were three ties,
and there were five years in which
the teams did not meet.
St. John's is a much older institution than Hopkins, and in the
earlier years had better facilities
for putting strong teams on the
field. It has not been many years
that Hopkins has had Homewood
Field, and many can remember
when the Black and Blue played
at Clifton Park to a non-paying attendance. In those days a hat was
passed around to cover expenses.
The keen rivalry which now exists between the teams had its inception about 1906. Since then
Hopkins has won four games, and
St. John's three. The 1907 game
was a tie.

A new addition to the athletic
program—a swimming team—is being agitated by a number of students, chief among them being
Henry Rowland and Richard Woodward.
The failure of the University to
be represented in the pool heretofore has been due to a lack of fast
swimmers and the consequent lack
of interest in this branch of sport.
However, this year sees us blessed
with an unusual number of good
men—a majority of whom are well
known in the South Atlantic Aquatic meets held annually at the Baltimore Athletic Club pool. Among
the pfomising candidates are Rowland, .the two Woodwards, Hoffman, Eiseman, W. Fulton, Penniman, Nicholson and a dozen or so
freshmen of experience.
Rowland has taken up the organization of the team in earnest,
having appIed for the use of the
Baltimore Athletic Club pool for
several days each week. This is
likely to be granted, and then the
swimmers will hold a meeting to
elect a captain and a manager and to
discuss plans for the season. Rowland hopes to be able to arrange
meets with Pennsylvania, Navy and
one or two other colleges, and also
with Hill School and Lawrenceville.
Possibly Princeton might be booked
for a meet in the big New Jersey
pool.
There is no doubt that the material here is of top-notch calibre.
Fulton and Dick Woodward are
former City College hundred-yard
champions, both being in the oneminute class. They are certainly
among the half-dozen fastest men
in the state. Hoffman is a fancy
diver who won a reputation at City
College also. Nicholson is a record
holder for the breast stroke, while
Eiseman is good in the dashes, having represented Doyle's Athletic
Club in several big meets. George
Penniman was interscholastic hundred-yard champion several years
ago and, although out of practice,
would undoubtedly prove a valuable
man for the relay team.
Of all the swimmers, however,
Rowland is the best known in local
circles. He sprang into prominence
by his work on Marston's team and
won particu'ar fame by carrying off
both the mo-yard and the 50-yard
in the City College-Freshman meet
two years ago. Since then he has
been improving rapidly. Although
prevented by illness from taking
part in the South Atlantics last
winter, he competed often this summer, winning the Bar Harbor meet
from some of the best Eastern college swimmers and tying the 45yard pool record there in 23/5 seconds. Lately he has been timed at
5 and 201/g seconds for the 40

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1914.
MIRZA FEARS A HOLY WAR

I RARE BOOKS GIVEN ECONOMICS
LIBRARY BY J. H. MITTENDORFF

Persian Student in Graduate Department
Believes Religious Conflict Inevitable.
Predicted Turkish Participation.

Lieutenant J. H. Mittendorff, late
past assistant engineer, United
States Navy, and -recording secretary of the local chapter of the National Marine Engineers' Beneficial
Association, has presented to Johns
Hopkins University a collection of
thirty volumes of the proceedings
of the national conventions of the
Association, the gift comprising an
addition to the library of trade
unionism that has been desired for
many years.
The books are the only collection
in existence,• with the exception of
those in the office of the headquarters of the Association and a
representative of Johns Hopkins
was sent to Detroit and Chicago
some time ago to try to get a duplicate set. When Lieutenant Mittendorff heard that the University
wanted the books, he gave them his
set. They wi I be brought to Hopkins this week.
The collection dates back to the
first convention and organization
meeting of the National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association.
The books, while of little significance to ordinary collectors, will
make an invaluable addition to the
Hopkins library section known as
".abor and capital." Students of
political economy base a large part
of their study on books such as are
included in the new gift, and it will
give them a new field for research.
Lieutenant Mittendorff, who lives
at 716 Dolphin street, is a collector
of stamps, coins and curios, and has
one ot the completest collections in
the city.

Youel P. Mirza, of Urumia, Persia, M. A., at present a graduate
student in the University, believes
that a holy war is inevitable. Some
time ago Mr. Mirza predicted that
Turkey wou'd enter the European
war as a German ally and at that
time he said that Turkish participation would bring about a religious
struggle of unprecedented limits.
In accordance with his prophecy,
Turkey has been drawn into the
struggle and Sheik-ul-Islam has declared a jehab, which is Persian for
a holy war.
Mr. Mirza has given his opinions
at some length in the feature article
of the current Outlook, and he reviewed his paper for a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER. He believes that the people in this country can scarcely calculate the power
that the Mohammedan religion
holds over its members, or what
hatred is felt toward the Christians
in Persia, who are there called the
giaours—the unclean. In speaking
of the Mohammedan desire for a
jehab, Mirza remarked, "I have
heard the Mohammedans almost
sigh for a holy war; I am persuaded
that they would not hesitate to come
back from Asia and Africa in answer to the cal of the sultan, and
if that unfortunate day ever dawns,
Allah help us."
It is interesting to note how
accurately one of our fellow students has predicted events which
have afterwards occurred. Although Mirza sees no other possibility, still he hopes that some other

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Students Mark Professors.
Students at the University of
Wisconsin are rejoicing at the novel
prospect of being in a position to
turn the tables and "mark" their
instructors and professors this year.
As part of their work in getting a
comprehensive view of the affairs
at the University a committee in
charge of the "university survey"
has supplied all the upperclassmen
with sets of questions to be answered and filed for reference.
The students may class their professors as "excellent," "good,"
"fair," "poor," and "very poor."
It is the purpose of the survey to
get criticism from every angle, and
suggestions and comments are desired.
*

*

*

Prohibitionists Active.
Nearly 2,5oo students in ioo colleges and universities of the United
States are studying the liquor problem in systematic classes under professional leadership, according to a
report of the Intercollegiate Prohibition Association. In thirty-four
of the colleges, regular curriculum
standing with college credit is given
for the study of the liquor question.

Free Ads in College Paper.
The Daily Kansan publishes free
of charge any advertisement in
which a student asks for work, or
an employer seeks student help.
This plan has proved a great success.

Offer Course on War.

New York University will this
year offer a special course on the
war. This course will begin with
a preliminary survey of the events
leading up to the conflict, going
back to the beginning of the development of the German Empire,
and coming down to the break between Austria and Servia.

$3,721,215 Budget.
According to the budget adopted
for the present academic year, it
will cost $3,721,215 to operate all
the departments of Columbia University from July I, 1914, to June
30, 1915. Nearly $800,000 of this
sum has been appropriated for the
care of buildings and grounds, for
the library, and for the redemption .
fund.

Not So Much the Quality of the Lecture
as the Closeness of Room That
Makes Students Drowsy.

The Cornell New Era asserts that
it's nothing against the quality or
delivery of lectures that so many
students slip into slumber during
classes. It's the poor ventilation of
the classrooms, says the paper,
which adds:
"It is little less than farcical to
hear a professor lecture earnestly
on the insanitary conditions of factories and sweatshops while the
sympathetic audience lapses slowly
into a lethargic condition, not because of the narcotic effect of the
lecture, but because of the air, or
rather the lack of it.
"Nothing cures 'that tired feeling' and promotes that alertness
which is essential to efficiency as
readily as plain, ordinary, unperfumed air. A lecture on personal
hygiene might in some cases prove
helpful to the atmosphere, but wideopen windows, even if they necessitated overcoats in classrooms,
would be a surer, better method.
"In fact, is not a man who goes
to sleep in a stuffy classroom, or
who deliberate,y 'cuts' the ordeal
of a lecture in such a place, showing his good horse sense?"
Louvain Professor at Harvard.

President Lowell of Harvard has
announced that he will offer a lectureship to one of the exiled Louvain professors early next year.
Nine professors of the Belgian institution are being cared for in
England by Mrs. Max Muller and
Lady Osler, who was Miss Revere
of Boston. Money for this purpose was raised by Lady Osler in
America.
The rector magnificus of Louvain fears that the Germans will
open a school at Louvain and claim
it as a continuation of the ancient
institution. A proposal has been
made to continue the life of the University in England, but it is feared
that few of the Belgian refugees
will have means to attend lectures.

In America these methods of
town planning are to be found in
many of its older cities. Annapolis
and Washington a r e radiating,
while Philadelphia is laid out in

The second lecture of the series
dealt with the evolution of municipal buildings. Around the market
cross in time a she•ter was built to
protect the people from the weather.
But when legislation became necessary in regard to forestalling, regrating and engrossing and other
market regulations, a second story
was added to the market cross
structure, where those in authority
might have an office. From this
beginning the town hall developed.
The old town hall of Boston is built
on this market-house plan, a:though
it never had any connection with
the market.
Next, Dr. Cunningham discussed
the development of the jail and
court, and while speaking of the
methods of punishment said, • "I
think it might be wise to revive
the stocks, even today, for petty
crimes." He showed how municipal buildings were built on the plan
of private houses and that the most
notable feature of our present public buildings, the dome, was introduced from the church through the
medium of the private house.
In his last lecture he discussed
the two great Anglo-Saxon emigrations—one to ancient Briton, the
other to America centuries later.
Those Englishmen who came to
America found very different conditions, however, than their ancestors. They did not find a civilization preceding them, nor were
they themselves as unorganized.
The form of government brought
to America shows clearly the European model—the manorial system
in Canada, New York and Virginia
and the township system in New
England.
When the Anglo-Saxons settled
in Britain their political boundaries
were defined often by geographical
features, since they were an agricultural people, and as they were
communal people they had those in
authority to manage the common
land, the market and other community affairs. By the time of
Elizabeth the township had become
most important and its officers
gradually wrested control from the
lord or baron. At this time emigration to America began and thus
we have here the highest form of
popular government as developed
in Eng:and.

Dr. Powell, since she has both a
charming personality and a fine
voice.
After a few words of introduction by President Goodnow, Dr.
Powell explained her thesis that
music is a human need. She told
of the new study, toneurology, the
effect of music upon the nervous
system of the individual and upon
that of society generally. "All the
motions of the body are rhythmical," and music has a practical
place in that it quiets the jarring
nerves and set up the rhythmic motions, which are so often disturbed
in daily life. "Try to chew your
food irregularly or walk unevenly
and you will soon find yourself becoming very nervous."
It is her belief that music will so
quiet a mob that it will be entirely
incapable of violence. Give your
audience but a short concert and the
most fiery orator will fail to move
them.
Besides its practical need we
.shou'd have free schools of music
to develop a national type. Oftentimes the common people are the
most musical. Beethoven, Mozart,
Schumann and others were of the
common people. However, Americans with talent, if poor, are unable to get the necessary training.
All European countries make large
-appropriations for music and only
by such a method will Americans
become a musical race.
In the second part of her lecturemusicale Dr. Powell sang a number
of selections illustrating the European types of music.

date is sixty-eight members, with
an average attendance of about
fifty. These figures are encouraging when the attendance of forme'
years is considered, but when compared with the total enrollment of
students in the University, cause a
certain disappointment. In consequence of this efforts are being
made to increase these figures.
Attendance at chapel services has
a!so been encouraging. For the
week of November 2 the average
attendance was thirty-four. The
following week this figure was
twenty-nine and last week twentyseven. These averages show a
slight decrease. Secretary Sutton
offers a possible explanation of this
by the fact that with the approach
of cold weather most students are
inclined to consider at too great
length the contrast between the
cold morning air and a warm bed.
Dr. Fisk, who led the services
last week, spoke on the "Privilege
of Power," Those students who
attended these services found Dr.
Fisk's talks very interesting and
practical. This week Emmette R.
Spencer will conduct the services.
In connection with the social
service work, recently started here
by the Association, Ryland Dempster has been assigned a class of
foreigners and illiterates at the City
Jail. Two other classes will be organized after Thanksgiving. Pierce
Hayes will conduct a class at the
Italian M. E. Church, 32 South
High street. Franklin Ebaugh will
have charge of the other class,
which will meet at 225 West Twenty-third street. Both classes will
meet on Thursday night.

With Arthur Train Is Co-Author of a
New War Serial in the Saturday Evening Post.

Those who have been reading
"The Man Who Rocked the Earth,"
a gripping war serial which is being published in the Saturday
Evening Post under the name of
Arthur Train, will doubtless be
interested to learn that Dr. Robert
W. Wood, professor of experimental physics, is a co-author of
the story.
Mr. Train, a grandson of George
Francis Train, the well known New
England writer, is assistant district
attorney of New York, and is now
engaged in prosecuting in the Siegel case. He devotes much of his
leisure time, however, to the writing of fiction, and has won some
degree of distinction in the magazine short-story field. He and Dr.
Wood came to the conclusion last
summer that a romance dealing
with the present world war, and
introducing many of the latest discoveries and theories of experimental physics, could not fail to be
of interest to a large number of
readers. They accordingly set
about writing "The Man Who
Rocked the Earth," and the immediate success of the story, as
evidenced by the general discussion
to which its publication has given
rise, proves that their surmise was
correct.
The serial, like Jack London's
"Iron Heel," and many of the novels of H. G. Wells, though it deals
with future events, is written in
the form of an historical narrative,
chronicling the occurrences of the
eventful month of July, 1915. The
introduction of new bombs, vortex
guns, and other novel instruments
for the waging of advanced warfare, increase the interest of the
'reader in this original enterprising
and timely romance. The contribution of scientific data was of course
the task of Dr. Wood, who also
wrote several of the passages dealing with more technical matters.
The greater part of the work of
sheer narrative construction was
left to Mr. Train.
The story opens with a short account of the history of the war
up to July I, 1915. It then tells
how Bill Hood, wireless operator
in the United States Observatory
at Washington, received a .mysterious message from a man who
demanded that the war come to
an end, appointed the United States
Government as the agency which
should assist him to carry his plans
to a successful conclusion, and
stated that, as a proof of his power
and authority to settle the question,
he would increase the length of the
ensuing stellar day, supposed to be
a fixed and changeless quantity, by
a period of five minutes.
The actual accomplishment of
this feat, and the many amazing
occurrences which ensued in breathless succession, are told graphically

7

23, 1914.

interesting story. Suffice it to remark here that the overwhelming
sweep of events that so signally
failed to move the stolid and unemotional Bill Hood are more than
sufficient to fire the interest and
enthusiasm of the most casual and
indifferent reader, who will certainly prove unable to resist the
fascination of the humor, adventure
and mystery that make up "The
Man Who Rocked the Earth."

SIR—The following verses, which
I recently heard recited in an alcohall, struck me as being so unusually
neutral that I thought you might
possib:y find room for them in your
columns. Be it distinctly understood that all rights are to be reserved, including those of translation into other languages, including the Scandanavian. Soft music:
The grape is laying many low,
The high ball swiftly whizzes,
And keen and shrill, on neighboring hill,
A deadly en gin-fizzes.
While kings, with "likerous intent"
In deadly deeds are vyin'
We're glad we took our Wilson straight,
Or Welched with Willy Bryan.
While German shell like heat of hell
Doth make the poor Scotch wry,
And many a soldier's bier is seen
That is not extra dry,
While men sham pain or feel it deep,
And many a lad is dyin',
We'll drink to Fate in Wilson straight,
Or grape with Willy Bryan.

Trusting that the unavoidably
rough sentiments expressed will, not
deprive this little gem of a popularity which it otherwise richly deserves, I am, sir,
Very sincerely yours,
G. B. S. ROTNASE.

The Debating Teams' Finances.
NOVEMBER 19, 1914.
of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Editor
To the

SIR—Some time ago there appeared in this column a letter deploring the sad state of the finances
of the Debate Council. May I, at
the risk of repeating what the
former writer on this matter said,
have some space in order to describe conditions as they actually
exist?
Every other student activity at
Hopkins has ample means of support. The Musical Clubs charge
an admission to their concerts.
THE NEWS-LETTER and Hullabaloo

have subscriptions, and advertising
space is sold. The Athletic Association gets fifty cents from everybody who sees the games at Homewood, holders of season tickets excepted, and in addition, it receives
ten dollars from every undergraduate at the University.
In the past the Debate Council
has had but seventy dollars a year.
It obtains fifty dollars from the
University and five from each of
the four classes. With this, it was
to pay for sending two men to
Charlottesville, two men to Chapel
Hill, N. C., besides holding two
debates in McCoy Hall with all the
concomitant incidentals—programs,
palms, tickets, postage, etc. The
result is that there has always been
a deficit which had to be made up
by the members of the teams and
others desiring to uphold Hopkins'
reputation in debating.
The Athletic Association has always managed to get along pretty
well in the past, and yet its income was, this year, increased more
than a thousand dollars by raising
the undergraduate assessment from
five dollars to ten.
There are a great many students
who never go into the gymnasium.
There are some who work Saturdays and who can not go to the
games, but they all pay their ten
dollars. Many of these take a
great interest in debating. Wouldn't
it be but fair if the Athletic Association would contribute something
to the support of that in which
these men are interested?
Respectfully,

MILLARD EISEMAN.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1914.

VARSITY SHOWED POOR OFFENSE

PRESIDENT GOODNOW FETED
Baltimore Alumni of Columbia Banquet
• Former Eton Professor at Maryland
Club—Distinguished Guests.

President Frank J. Goodnow was
the guest of honor at a banquet
given Saturday night at the Maryland Club by the Baltimore alumni
of Columbia University in which
Dr. Goodnow was a professor before being called to the presidency
of Johns Hopkins.
As a special compliment to President Goodnow there were among
the speakers Dr. Nicholas Murray
Butler, president of Columbia; Prof.
Talcott Williams, dean of the Pulitzer School of Journalism of Columbia, and Benjamin B. Lawrence,
a mining engineer of New York
and the first trustee of Columbia
elected by the alumni organization.
N. Winslow Williams, former
Secretary of State of Maryland,
who was graduated from Columbia
in 1883, was toastmaster, and
among the 6o guests were several
from out of the city, in addition
to the speakers. These included
James Brown Scott, secretary of
the Carnegie Peace Endowment,
of Washington, and Dr. Marcus
Benjamin, who is president of the
Columbia Alumni Club of that city.
There were no set speeches, but
the general trend of the extemporaneous remarks was congratulation to Baltimore that Hopkins had
been so fortunate as to obtain for
its head a man of the calibre and
learning of Dr. Goodnow. From
President Butler came the note of
regret that Dr. Goodnow had decided to leave Columbia.
While most of the speeches were
by no means serious, President
Goodnow took occasion to touch
upon the big problem which confronts him as executive head of
such an institution as Hopkins. He
declared that ever since his arrival
he had been asked what his policy
would be with respect to the University.
"It is. hard for me to make them
understand," he explained, "that I
have no policy yet; that before
making any plans for the future
which might affect the administration of the affairs of the University I will first have to study the
situation with utmost care and find
out what is best to be done."
Dr. William H. Welch, whose
speech followed that of the toastmaster, referred to the care with
which the trustees of Hopkins had
selected its president.
His remarks were recalled by
President Butler, who complained
that Columbia was getting to be too
much of a national market for university presidents and professors,

NEW POWER-HOUSE AT HOMEWOOD NEARING COMPLETION

The interior of the power-house
at Homewood has taken on quite a
changed appearance in the past
few weeks. Bricklayers, boiler
setters and pipe fitters have gone.
In their place there are a few
negroes straightening up, and a
few electricians connecting the dynamos and switchboards.
In the boiler-room one finds all
four boilers bricked in, and one
burning in order to heat the buildings which are now in use. It is
one of the two equipped with the
Ronney mechanical stokers, and the
ease with which it may be attended
would make old Mr. Sapp, who
fires the boilers in McCoy Hall,
quite envious. The other boiler,
equipped with the Ronney stoker,
is finished, as are also the two of
the Taylor blast type. The stack
is now being put on the superheater, and when this is done the
boiler-room will be finished.
In the pumproom adjoining,
everything is also practically completed, and the feed pumps are
working.
The three dynamos, two turbines
and one reciprocating engine, which
together comprise three units, are
all set up in the engine room, and
only need a few connections before
they begin generating current. The
switch boards which control the
whole of the new plant are also in
this room, and are now being
wired. For the. present light is obtained from outside sources. The
engine room is directly over the
pumproom.
It is only in the northern part
of the power-house where the gas
and steam engine laboratories are
to be that the incomplete appearance remains. This is because
much of the machinery has not yet
come, and because most of the
contractor's efforts have been toward getting the boilers ready.
Now that this work has been
finished, work on the laboratory
(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

GLEE CLUB MAKES GREAT
STRIDES WITH NEW MUSIC

The members of the .\ I usical
Clubs are hard at work. Under
the direction of their respective
leaders, the Glee and Instrumental
squads have been rehearsing diligently at frequent intervals and are
producing results which promise
something really good at concerts
of the coming season. The Glee
Club has made remarkable strides.
In one of the recent rehearsals an
entire song was worked through.
The Instrumental men have some
rather difficult music to learn, and
in spite of the fact that they rehearse only once a week, have accomplished much. The music to
be rendered this year by both clubs
has been pronounced by those who
have heard it the best that the clubs
have ever had, and with the new
plans of handling the men, especially on the Glee Club, a wellrounded aggregation .of musicians
is expected to represent Johns Hopkins this year.
Concerts will be arranged in the
near future, the first to take place
probably about Christmas time. A
Christmas trip will not be taken this
year, owing to the short time which
the clubs have had for preparation,
and to the fact that it is very hard
to pay bills for a Christmas trip at
the beginning of the season, when
there is very little money in the
treasury. The bad debts due to
trips such as these are what the
present management is trying to
avoid altogether, in order to place
the organization on a firm financial
basis. Therefore, whatever trips
are made will be taken after there
has been some money made through
chnrch concerts and other local engagements, Mills for some very
attractive trips are being considered
by the Board of Governors.

Played Creditable Defensive Came, But
Attack Was Disappointing—Western
Maryland Won,6 to 0.
By AN OLD PLAYER.

The fact that Coach Cates was
not at Homewood to see the game
between Johns Hopkins and West
em Maryland will save the members of our team from the good
scolding which they deserve. Western Maryland won by a score of
6 to o. It would have been larger
had not the 'Varsity played such
a creditable defensive game.
But it makes no difference how
strong the defense is, a team is
worth very little or nothing if it
has not developed a good attack.
Hopkins has, or had, an attack that
was excellent—we need only to
look to the Gettysburg and Washington College games to see this.
But on Saturday the attack was
not strong enough to make more
than a couple of first downs. Why?
The backfield men stopped whenever a tackle was imminent. Bob
Hoffman was the only man who
made his tacklers work. The
others slowed down as soon as an
arm was raised before them.
Furthermore, there was no interference worth mentioning. The
squad has worked hard to develop
plays which specify a definite interference for the man with the
ball. The plays work well in practice: there is always a man before
the runner. But on Saturday, it
appeared that a lesson had never
been given in interference.
And what is more, I have never
seen a team so slow in signals, in
passing the ball and in getting off
on a run. Every second must
count; you know that: But a regular sermon in signals was read
off to the players. It took nearly
three-quarters of.a minute to pass
around the numbers for the play,
and many times it was necessary to
hold a little consultation in which
the numbers were explained. Why
should this be? Doesn't every man
know the signals? Captain Wilkinson was not wholly to blame for
this condition. It took him a long
time to call the signals, but it was
apparently necessary, for the backfield (with the exception of Hoffman) did not readily grasp them.
The defeat may be ascribed to
the slowness of the backfield and
its lack of "pep." I hope this will
not be the case in the St. John's
game. It would be better for the
men to sit up all night and learn
the signals than to have had sleep
and not know them in the most important game of the season.
But the lack of attack was neutralized by the excellent offense.

FINAL BATTLE WITH ST. JOHN'S

A SWIMMING TEAM PROPOSED

'Varsity's Rivals From Annapolis Wil
Close Football Season Thanksgiving.
Records Since 1888.

With the Number of Good Men Available
It Is Hoped Team Can Be Formed
to Represent Hopkins.

St. John's College, boasting one
of the strongest and best balanced
football teams it has ever had, will
meet the 'Varsity Thanksgiving
afternoon in the final game of the
season. The Annapolis team is
slightly the favorite, but Hopkins
is unwilling to concede that it will
have a walk-away as St. John's
now predicts.
The team will come to Baltimore supported by the entire student body, and will have a band.
Hopkins, too, will turn out in solid
• array, and will have its hired
musicians, as is customary for this
occasion. There will be a massmeeting in Hopkins Hall at one
o'clock Wednesday, at which details for assembling and cheering
stand arrangement will be explained.
Johns Hopkins and St. John's
have met on the gridiron twentyfour times since 1888. St. John's
has won twelve games, and Hopkins nine. There were three ties,
and there were five years in which
the teams did not meet.
St. John's is a much older institution than Hopkins, and in the
earlier years had better facilities
for putting strong teams on the
field. It has not been many years
that Hopkins has had Homewood
Field, and many can remember
when the Black and Blue played
at Clifton Park to a non-paying attendance. In those days a hat was
passed around to cover expenses.
The keen rivalry which now exists between the teams had its inception about 1906. Since then
Hopkins has won four games, and
St. John's three. The 1907 game
was a tie.
The scores since 1888 follow:

A new addition to the athletic
program—a swimming team—is being agitated by a number of students, chief among them being
Henry Rowland and Richard Woodward.
The failure of the University to
be represented in the pool heretofore has been due to a lack of fast
swimmers and the consequent lack
of interest in this branch of sport.
However, this year sees us blessed
with an unusual number of good
men—a majority of whom are well
known in the South Atlantic Aquatic meets held annually at the Baltimore Athletic Club pool. Among
the pfomising candidates are Rowland, .the two Woodwards, Hoffman, Eiseman, W. Fulton, Penniman, Nicholson and a dozen or so
freshmen of experience.
Rowland has taken up the organization of the team in earnest,
having appIed for the use of the
Baltimore Athletic Club pool for
several days each week. This is
likely to be granted, and then the
swimmers will hold a meeting to
elect a captain and a manager and to
discuss plans for the season. Rowland hopes to be able to arrange
meets with Pennsylvania, Navy and
one or two other colleges, and also
with Hill School and Lawrenceville.
Possibly Princeton might be booked
for a meet in the big New Jersey
pool.
There is no doubt that the material here is of top-notch calibre.
Fulton and Dick Woodward are
former City College hundred-yard
champions, both being in the oneminute class. They are certainly
among the half-dozen fastest men
in the state. Hoffman is a fancy
diver who won a reputation at City
College also. Nicholson is a record
holder for the breast stroke, while
Eiseman is good in the dashes, having represented Doyle's Athletic
Club in several big meets. George
Penniman was interscholastic hundred-yard champion several years
ago and, although out of practice,
would undoubtedly prove a valuable
man for the relay team.
Of all the swimmers, however,
Rowland is the best known in local
circles. He sprang into prominence
by his work on Marston's team and
won particu'ar fame by carrying off
both the mo-yard and the 50-yard
in the City College-Freshman meet
two years ago. Since then he has
been improving rapidly. Although
prevented by illness from taking
part in the South Atlantics last
winter, he competed often this summer, winning the Bar Harbor meet
from some of the best Eastern college swimmers and tying the 45yard pool record there in 23/5 seconds. Lately he has been timed at

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1914.
MIRZA FEARS A HOLY WAR

I RARE BOOKS GIVEN ECONOMICS
LIBRARY BY J. H. MITTENDORFF

Persian Student in Graduate Department
Believes Religious Conflict Inevitable.
Predicted Turkish Participation.

Lieutenant J. H. Mittendorff, late
past assistant engineer, United
States Navy, and -recording secretary of the local chapter of the National Marine Engineers' Beneficial
Association, has presented to Johns
Hopkins University a collection of
thirty volumes of the proceedings
of the national conventions of the
Association, the gift comprising an
addition to the library of trade
unionism that has been desired for
many years.
The books are the only collection
in existence,• with the exception of
those in the office of the headquarters of the Association and a
representative of Johns Hopkins
was sent to Detroit and Chicago
some time ago to try to get a duplicate set. When Lieutenant Mittendorff heard that the University
wanted the books, he gave them his
set. They wi I be brought to Hopkins this week.
The collection dates back to the
first convention and organization
meeting of the National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association.
The books, while of little significance to ordinary collectors, will
make an invaluable addition to the
Hopkins library section known as
".abor and capital." Students of
political economy base a large part
of their study on books such as are
included in the new gift, and it will
give them a new field for research.
Lieutenant Mittendorff, who lives
at 716 Dolphin street, is a collector
of stamps, coins and curios, and has
one ot the completest collections in
the city.

Youel P. Mirza, of Urumia, Persia, M. A., at present a graduate
student in the University, believes
that a holy war is inevitable. Some
time ago Mr. Mirza predicted that
Turkey wou'd enter the European
war as a German ally and at that
time he said that Turkish participation would bring about a religious
struggle of unprecedented limits.
In accordance with his prophecy,
Turkey has been drawn into the
struggle and Sheik-ul-Islam has declared a jehab, which is Persian for
a holy war.
Mr. Mirza has given his opinions
at some length in the feature article
of the current Outlook, and he reviewed his paper for a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER. He believes that the people in this country can scarcely calculate the power
that the Mohammedan religion
holds over its members, or what
hatred is felt toward the Christians
in Persia, who are there called the
giaours—the unclean. In speaking
of the Mohammedan desire for a
jehab, Mirza remarked, "I have
heard the Mohammedans almost
sigh for a holy war; I am persuaded
that they would not hesitate to come
back from Asia and Africa in answer to the cal of the sultan, and
if that unfortunate day ever dawns,
Allah help us."
It is interesting to note how
accurately one of our fellow students has predicted events which
have afterwards occurred. Although Mirza sees no other possibility, still he hopes that some other

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Students Mark Professors.
Students at the University of
Wisconsin are rejoicing at the novel
prospect of being in a position to
turn the tables and "mark" their
instructors and professors this year.
As part of their work in getting a
comprehensive view of the affairs
at the University a committee in
charge of the "university survey"
has supplied all the upperclassmen
with sets of questions to be answered and filed for reference.
The students may class their professors as "excellent," "good,"
"fair," "poor," and "very poor."
It is the purpose of the survey to
get criticism from every angle, and
suggestions and comments are desired.
*

*

*

Prohibitionists Active.
Nearly 2,5oo students in ioo colleges and universities of the United
States are studying the liquor problem in systematic classes under professional leadership, according to a
report of the Intercollegiate Prohibition Association. In thirty-four
of the colleges, regular curriculum
standing with college credit is given
for the study of the liquor question.

Free Ads in College Paper.
The Daily Kansan publishes free
of charge any advertisement in
which a student asks for work, or
an employer seeks student help.
This plan has proved a great success.

Offer Course on War.

New York University will this
year offer a special course on the
war. This course will begin with
a preliminary survey of the events
leading up to the conflict, going
back to the beginning of the development of the German Empire,
and coming down to the break between Austria and Servia.

According to the budget adopted
for the present academic year, it
will cost $3,721,215 to operate all
the departments of Columbia University from July I, 1914, to June
30, 1915. Nearly $800,000 of this
sum has been appropriated for the
care of buildings and grounds, for
the library, and for the redemption .
fund.

Not So Much the Quality of the Lecture
as the Closeness of Room That
Makes Students Drowsy.

The Cornell New Era asserts that
it's nothing against the quality or
delivery of lectures that so many
students slip into slumber during
classes. It's the poor ventilation of
the classrooms, says the paper,
which adds:
"It is little less than farcical to
hear a professor lecture earnestly
on the insanitary conditions of factories and sweatshops while the
sympathetic audience lapses slowly
into a lethargic condition, not because of the narcotic effect of the
lecture, but because of the air, or
rather the lack of it.
"Nothing cures 'that tired feeling' and promotes that alertness
which is essential to efficiency as
readily as plain, ordinary, unperfumed air. A lecture on personal
hygiene might in some cases prove
helpful to the atmosphere, but wideopen windows, even if they necessitated overcoats in classrooms,
would be a surer, better method.
"In fact, is not a man who goes
to sleep in a stuffy classroom, or
who deliberate,y 'cuts' the ordeal
of a lecture in such a place, showing his good horse sense?"
Louvain Professor at Harvard.

President Lowell of Harvard has
announced that he will offer a lectureship to one of the exiled Louvain professors early next year.
Nine professors of the Belgian institution are being cared for in
England by Mrs. Max Muller and
Lady Osler, who was Miss Revere
of Boston. Money for this purpose was raised by Lady Osler in
America.
The rector magnificus of Louvain fears that the Germans will
open a school at Louvain and claim
it as a continuation of the ancient
institution. A proposal has been
made to continue the life of the University in England, but it is feared
that few of the Belgian refugees
will have means to attend lectures.

The Roman town, with its two
Twigg, full, and Fulton, quarter. main streets intersecting in the midAbout eight men are trying for dle, fashioned after the Roman casend positions, giving Gorman plenty tra; the rectangular town, built on

to Europe after the Crusades; the

In America these methods of
town planning are to be found in
many of its older cities. Annapolis
and Washington a r e radiating,
while Philadelphia is laid out in

The second lecture of the series
dealt with the evolution of municipal buildings. Around the market
cross in time a she•ter was built to
protect the people from the weather.
But when legislation became necessary in regard to forestalling, regrating and engrossing and other
market regulations, a second story
was added to the market cross
structure, where those in authority
might have an office. From this
beginning the town hall developed.
The old town hall of Boston is built
on this market-house plan, a:though
it never had any connection with
the market.
Next, Dr. Cunningham discussed
the development of the jail and
court, and while speaking of the
methods of punishment said, • "I
think it might be wise to revive
the stocks, even today, for petty
crimes." He showed how municipal buildings were built on the plan
of private houses and that the most
notable feature of our present public buildings, the dome, was introduced from the church through the
medium of the private house.
In his last lecture he discussed
the two great Anglo-Saxon emigrations—one to ancient Briton, the
other to America centuries later.
Those Englishmen who came to
America found very different conditions, however, than their ancestors. They did not find a civilization preceding them, nor were
they themselves as unorganized.
The form of government brought
to America shows clearly the European model—the manorial system
in Canada, New York and Virginia
and the township system in New
England.
When the Anglo-Saxons settled
in Britain their political boundaries
were defined often by geographical
features, since they were an agricultural people, and as they were
communal people they had those in
authority to manage the common
land, the market and other community affairs. By the time of
Elizabeth the township had become
most important and its officers
gradually wrested control from the
lord or baron. At this time emigration to America began and thus
we have here the highest form of
popular government as developed
in Eng:and.

Dr. Powell, since she has both a
charming personality and a fine
voice.
After a few words of introduction by President Goodnow, Dr.
Powell explained her thesis that
music is a human need. She told
of the new study, toneurology, the
effect of music upon the nervous
system of the individual and upon
that of society generally. "All the
motions of the body are rhythmical," and music has a practical
place in that it quiets the jarring
nerves and set up the rhythmic motions, which are so often disturbed
in daily life. "Try to chew your
food irregularly or walk unevenly
and you will soon find yourself becoming very nervous."
It is her belief that music will so
quiet a mob that it will be entirely
incapable of violence. Give your
audience but a short concert and the
most fiery orator will fail to move
them.
Besides its practical need we
.shou'd have free schools of music
to develop a national type. Oftentimes the common people are the
most musical. Beethoven, Mozart,
Schumann and others were of the
common people. However, Americans with talent, if poor, are unable to get the necessary training.
All European countries make large
-appropriations for music and only
by such a method will Americans
become a musical race.
In the second part of her lecturemusicale Dr. Powell sang a number
of selections illustrating the European types of music.

Coming "THE MASTER MIND"
Y. M. C. A. ENROLLS SIXTYEIGHT BIBLE CLASS STUDENTS

The Bible classes of the University Young Men's Christian Association are organized and meeting
regularly. The total enrollment to
date is sixty-eight members, with
an average attendance of about
fifty. These figures are encouraging when the attendance of forme'
years is considered, but when compared with the total enrollment of
students in the University, cause a
certain disappointment. In consequence of this efforts are being
made to increase these figures.
Attendance at chapel services has
a!so been encouraging. For the
week of November 2 the average
attendance was thirty-four. The
following week this figure was
twenty-nine and last week twentyseven. These averages show a
slight decrease. Secretary Sutton
offers a possible explanation of this
by the fact that with the approach
of cold weather most students are
inclined to consider at too great
length the contrast between the
cold morning air and a warm bed.
Dr. Fisk, who led the services
last week, spoke on the "Privilege
of Power," Those students who
attended these services found Dr.
Fisk's talks very interesting and
practical. This week Emmette R.
Spencer will conduct the services.
In connection with the social
service work, recently started here
by the Association, Ryland Dempster has been assigned a class of
foreigners and illiterates at the City
Jail. Two other classes will be organized after Thanksgiving. Pierce
Hayes will conduct a class at the
Italian M. E. Church, 32 South
High street. Franklin Ebaugh will
have charge of the other class,
which will meet at 225 West Twenty-third street. Both classes will
meet on Thursday night.

With Arthur Train Is Co-Author of a
New War Serial in the Saturday Evening Post.

Those who have been reading
"The Man Who Rocked the Earth,"
a gripping war serial which is being published in the Saturday
Evening Post under the name of
Arthur Train, will doubtless be
interested to learn that Dr. Robert
W. Wood, professor of experimental physics, is a co-author of
the story.
Mr. Train, a grandson of George
Francis Train, the well known New
England writer, is assistant district
attorney of New York, and is now
engaged in prosecuting in the Siegel case. He devotes much of his
leisure time, however, to the writing of fiction, and has won some
degree of distinction in the magazine short-story field. He and Dr.
Wood came to the conclusion last
summer that a romance dealing
with the present world war, and
introducing many of the latest discoveries and theories of experimental physics, could not fail to be
of interest to a large number of
readers. They accordingly set
about writing "The Man Who
Rocked the Earth," and the immediate success of the story, as
evidenced by the general discussion
to which its publication has given
rise, proves that their surmise was
correct.
The serial, like Jack London's
"Iron Heel," and many of the novels of H. G. Wells, though it deals
with future events, is written in
the form of an historical narrative,
chronicling the occurrences of the
eventful month of July, 1915. The
introduction of new bombs, vortex
guns, and other novel instruments
for the waging of advanced warfare, increase the interest of the
'reader in this original enterprising
and timely romance. The contribution of scientific data was of course
the task of Dr. Wood, who also
wrote several of the passages dealing with more technical matters.
The greater part of the work of
sheer narrative construction was
left to Mr. Train.
The story opens with a short account of the history of the war
up to July I, 1915. It then tells
how Bill Hood, wireless operator
in the United States Observatory
at Washington, received a .mysterious message from a man who
demanded that the war come to
an end, appointed the United States
Government as the agency which
should assist him to carry his plans
to a successful conclusion, and
stated that, as a proof of his power
and authority to settle the question,
he would increase the length of the
ensuing stellar day, supposed to be
a fixed and changeless quantity, by
a period of five minutes.
The actual accomplishment of
this feat, and the many amazing
occurrences which ensued in breathless succession, are told graphically

7

23, 1914.

interesting story. Suffice it to remark here that the overwhelming
sweep of events that so signally
failed to move the stolid and unemotional Bill Hood are more than
sufficient to fire the interest and
enthusiasm of the most casual and
indifferent reader, who will certainly prove unable to resist the
fascination of the humor, adventure
and mystery that make up "The
Man Who Rocked the Earth."

SIR—The following verses, which
I recently heard recited in an alcohall, struck me as being so unusually
neutral that I thought you might
possib:y find room for them in your
columns. Be it distinctly understood that all rights are to be reserved, including those of translation into other languages, including the Scandanavian. Soft music:
The grape is laying many low,
The high ball swiftly whizzes,
And keen and shrill, on neighboring hill,
A deadly en gin-fizzes.
While kings, with "likerous intent"
In deadly deeds are vyin'
We're glad we took our Wilson straight,
Or Welched with Willy Bryan.
While German shell like heat of hell
Doth make the poor Scotch wry,
And many a soldier's bier is seen
That is not extra dry,
While men sham pain or feel it deep,
And many a lad is dyin',
We'll drink to Fate in Wilson straight,
Or grape with Willy Bryan.

Trusting that the unavoidably
rough sentiments expressed will, not
deprive this little gem of a popularity which it otherwise richly deserves, I am, sir,
Very sincerely yours,
G. B. S. ROTNASE.

The Debating Teams' Finances.
NOVEMBER 19, 1914.
of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Editor
To the

SIR—Some time ago there appeared in this column a letter deploring the sad state of the finances
of the Debate Council. May I, at
the risk of repeating what the
former writer on this matter said,
have some space in order to describe conditions as they actually
exist?
Every other student activity at
Hopkins has ample means of support. The Musical Clubs charge
an admission to their concerts.
THE NEWS-LETTER and Hullabaloo

have subscriptions, and advertising
space is sold. The Athletic Association gets fifty cents from everybody who sees the games at Homewood, holders of season tickets excepted, and in addition, it receives
ten dollars from every undergraduate at the University.
In the past the Debate Council
has had but seventy dollars a year.
It obtains fifty dollars from the
University and five from each of
the four classes. With this, it was
to pay for sending two men to
Charlottesville, two men to Chapel
Hill, N. C., besides holding two
debates in McCoy Hall with all the
concomitant incidentals—programs,
palms, tickets, postage, etc. The
result is that there has always been
a deficit which had to be made up
by the members of the teams and
others desiring to uphold Hopkins'
reputation in debating.
The Athletic Association has always managed to get along pretty
well in the past, and yet its income was, this year, increased more
than a thousand dollars by raising
the undergraduate assessment from
five dollars to ten.
There are a great many students
who never go into the gymnasium.
There are some who work Saturdays and who can not go to the
games, but they all pay their ten
dollars. Many of these take a
great interest in debating. Wouldn't
it be but fair if the Athletic Association would contribute something
to the support of that in which
these men are interested?
Respectfully,

MILLARD EISEMAN.
